text: We are looking at Page 60 that we worked on, on Tuesday.  And the first problem – Student [Inaudible], can you read us the first problem, please?

text: Sandra and Tyler made two loaves of bread.  On Monday they ate one half of a loaf.  On Tuesday they ate one third of a loaf.  How much bread was left?

text: Thank you.  So, I drew the two loaves of bread.  What I realized on Tuesday was we’ve done a lot of talking about fractions.  We’ve done a lot of talking about [Inaudible] fractions.  We’ve done a lot of talking about fraction [graphs], but for some reason we are not able to take all of that and put it together and then add the fractions together.  So I wanted to talk about that before we got into our small groups. So, [Inaudible], please.  So I drew the two loaves of bread.  We’re assuming the two loaves of bread are the same size.  On Monday, they ate how much bread?  Student L?

text: On Monday, they ate one half.

Is there a denominator – hold on a second until I finish my [Inaudible].  Is there a denominator that they could have in common? And we can do that a couple of different ways.  We can use the clock.
